_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Area and Perimeter detectors annunciate in Houston Control.  In addition, video survellance camera that is available at any time, day or night by dial-up connection to Houston Control.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Enterprise utilizes a fourteen issue accidnt prevention / safety management program to comply with the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management Program and the EPA Risk Management Program.  The program includes issues dealing with employee participation, operator training, management of change, process hazard analysis, facility maintenance, hot work and other practices designed to insure the safe design, operation, maintenance and modification of the plant.  Additional details on the Farmington Terminal accident prevention program are included in the Executive Summary.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Environmental Protection Agency Risk Management Plan
Enterprise Farmington Terminal & Storage
Risk Management Plan (RMP)
Executive Summary

At the Enterprise Farmington Terminal and Storage, we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.

The Enterprise Farmington Terminal and Storage is owned by Enterprise Terminal & Storage, LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Mapletree, LLC and operated by Enterprise Products Operating LLC(Enterprise).

We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help provide for the safety of our employees and the public, as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the risk management measures that we have designed and implemented, including:

* A description of our facility and use of substances required by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP regulation and the processes involved
* A summary of results from our assessment of the potential offsite consequences from accidental chemical releases
* Emergency Response Programs
* General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
* A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals at the Farmington Terminal that are regulated by EPA's RMP rule.  

Facility Description

The Farmington Terminal is a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) pipeline and propane storage/loading facility.  The process is regulated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration under 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR Part 68.  We have entered the facility as an RMP Program Level 3 facility.

The Farmington Terminal has a single Department of Transportation regulated pipeline

that is routed into the facility.  This pipeline is a dedicated propane line.  The Farmington facility receives propane from the pipeline to two propane storage tanks.  These tanks are used for distribution to the truck transport loading docks which also has capabilities to stench the propane for retail sales companies.  All of these tanks are administratively controlled to hold and not exceed 85% of their capacity.

In our process we use the following chemicals that the EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequence in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Toxics

No toxic materials to report.

Flammables

Propane is delivered into two storage tanks via the dedicated propane pipeline.  This material is routed from these tanks to the four truck transport loading docks for wholesale distribution to propane retailers.

A small quantity of Ethyl Mercaptan is used to stench the propane at the truck transport docks.  Ethyl mercaptan is stored at the terminal in an amount below the threshold quantity specified in the RMP regulation.

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis Scenarios

The EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s) for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.

Worst Case Release Scenario - Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Farmington Terminal.

Alternate Release Scenario(s) - Regulated Toxic Chemical

There are no regulated toxic chemicals to report for the Farmington Terminal.

Worse Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

This simulation involves the rupture or failure of one of the propane storage tanks resulting in a simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumes there would be no mitigation.  All emergency respo

nse and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  Either the local emergency shutdown would be activated and/or Houston Control would activate the emergency shutdown system remotely.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation and the specifics of the simulation are available in the specified reporting of the Risk Management Plan

Alternate Case Scenario - Regulated Flammable Chemicals

The alternate release scenario is a simulated rupture of the supply pipe to the loading docks resulting in a ten minute release and simulated vapor cloud explosion.  This scenario assumed the pump continued to operate at its design flow rate for 10 minutes after the line break.  Mitigation measures were taken into account when selecting the alternative release scenario.  These measures consisted of reviewing the use of relief valves, check valves, manual shutoff valves, automatic shutoffs, startup and operating procedures, grounding equipment, and excess flow devices.  Activation of the Emergency Shutdown Devices would isolate the source of the material and secure the facility.  All emergency response and early warning procedures to inform employees and the community would be exercised immediately if this were to occur.  The quantity and endpoint of the simulation is contained in the data elements.

We are using this information to help us ensure that our emergency response plan and the community emergency response plan address a reasonable range of contingencies.

Emergency Response Program

Enterprise maintains an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning and reporting.  The program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Furthermore, the plan is coordinated with the Farmington County Sheriff's Depar

tment who dispatches the necessary Fire Department and Emergency Medical Service.

In the event of an accidental release, local Enterprise personnel are trained to sound the alarm, shut off the source from a safe location or activate the emergency shutdown system, contact 9-1-1 and secure the area.  The 9-1-1 system will be used to notify the Farmington County Emergency Communications Center which will make notification to the local law enforcement and Fire Department(s).  Remote activation can also be accomplished from EnterpriseA?s Houston Control which has area video cameras with dial-up access.  In addition, there are local gas detection systems that alarm locally and in Houston Control.  If these detectors annunciate, the facility can be shut down remotely from Houston Control or locally by operations personnel.  A third-party contractor, 3E Company is under contract to contact the necessary agencies if required.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Enterprise takes a systematic, protective approach to preventing accidental release of hazardous chemicals.  Our Process Safety Management systems address each of the key features of a successful prevention program, including:

* Process safety information
* Process hazard analysis
* Operating procedures
* Training
* Mechanical integrity
* Management of change
* Pre-Startup Safety Review - "PSSR"
* Compliance audits
* Incident investigation
* Employee participation
* Hot work permit
* Contractors

As a part of our prevention efforts, Enterprise employees participate in numerous safety and training programs.  A training program has been developed in which Operations and Maintenance personnel are specifically trained in the operation of the facility, the operating procedures, maintenance procedures, and specific other regulations and policies, as well as in all areas of emergency response.  Employees are trained on, use, and apply the guidelines of our PSM program, w

hich include all of the above-listed areas.  All of these programs come under scheduled scrutiny and critique.

There is an on-going inspection program designed to search out and find deficiencies with the process equipment prior to any incident.

Operations personnel make regular inspections of the equipment and processes they operate.  If something out of the ordinary is found, it is reported to management in order to expediently resolve any problems.

The engineering and administrative controls in place have been established to reduce the risk of an accidental release of identified hazards.  Enterprise is committed to operations that are safe for employees and the surrounding community.

Accident History

Records are kept for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility.  The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years:

Based on the criteria set forth in 40 CFR 68.10, this facility has not had an accidental release.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The following is a list of improvements that are planned for implementation at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

* The Enterprise accident prevention / PSM program is currently being reviewed and updated to improve the program.
* Additional access platforms have recently been added to the terminal to improve technician access to terminal equipment, reducing the possibility of employee injury or a release of flammable material caused by a human factor issue.  
* A new propane receipt meter has been installed on the product delivery line to allow for improved flow rate control over a wider range of propane product delivery rates.
